topic.title: matrix.org is a ZeroNet Analogue for VoIP
topic.body:
The beauty of the ZeroNet is that the original server/node that created the web page, can go offline and as long as the servers/nodes that viewed the page stay online, the page stays online. 
The 
https://matrix.org/
network aims to be the tool for a TODALLY DIFFERENT USE CASE, which is real time phone calls over an open source P2P network. The ZeroNet and the matrix.org are complementary technologies. The matrix.org can also be used for implementing chat rooms, which are also possible on the ZeroNet. 
https://riot.im/app/#/home

The server/node side of both, the ZeroNet and the matrix.org seem to be implemented in Python.

I find the matrix.org to be analogous to the ZeroNet in at least 2 ways:

1) The matrix.org is not a "venture capital"(read: loan shark) financed project, which means that its developers can take decisions calmly on the basis of their technical preferences and the software development decisions are not influenced by a need to get a "new round" of "venture capital" money or an urge to make a start-up company as visible as possible to get a better price at some corporate acquisition or IPO(Initial Public Offering). The matrix.org developers can take their time at developing features and they can focus on technical quality in stead of being rushed to demonstrate something to the investors or potential buyers. I find the technical quality to be critical for any project that aims to be a base technology for other software projects. For example, in my very subjective view the 
https://diasporafoundation.org/
clearly lacks technical quality, because its dependencies seem to be chosen hastily, it is truly difficult to set up a Diaspora node. If the Diaspora developers had had just TESTED, what has to be done to set up their own software on major Linux distributions, the number of steps, all the configuration, then clearly they would have noticed that they need to change the Diaspora radically to make its installation more robust, manageable, but the Diaspora was a crowdfunded project, where the developers had an urge to publish whatever they can publish to show the masses of backers that they deliver on their promises and the rushing related LACK OF TECHNICAL QUALITY really shows. Typical "P2P start-up" companies have both, the rushing related problems and also the "legal" problem, because the investors of the startup want to sell the start-up to some megacororation that operates in some specific "jurisdiction". Neither the ZeroNet, nor the matrix.org, has that problem and that makes them both technically much more elegant, although, as of 2017_10 I find that the ZeroNet source has higher quality than the matrix.org has, because some of the matrix.org dependencies seem to require PyPy at installation, while the ZeroNet works just fine with the classical Python.


2) The matrix.org and the ZeroNet are both analogous to each other also from that point of view that they both require its users to run a node at LAN, unlike the Diaspora, which acts as an ordinary remotely hosted web application that just happens to use P2P between servers.

All in all, according to my personal taste I like the ZeroNet more than the matrix.org, because the ZeroNet developers have paid closer attention to the portability and ease of installation of the ZeroNet than the matrix.org developers have paid to the portability and ease of installation of their project software. My observation is that projects that are founded or lead by non-technical people, for example, journalists, lawyers, etc. tend to be technically crappier than projects that are founded and led by software developers, who want to keep a low profile and concentrate on the technical quality of the project, not huge crowds of fans of the project. If the non-technical guys hire or lobby to join technical guys, then the tech guys need to react to the wishes of their non-technical team-mates/clients and that leads to the pressure to publish/demonstrate_results. Any kind of rush and such kind of pressure is REALLY BAD for the technical quality of the project. In a proper situation software developers are free to declare calmly that they screwed up and need to start from scratch and that starting form the scratch, even if it's just a sub-component that needs to be totally overhauled, is what keeps the technical quality of the software project at high level,  but it's not an easy task to declare to investors of a start-up company or backers of a crowdfunded project that sorry, we screwed up and need to ditch the software that You paid us to develop and start the implementation effort from scratch. So they publish, even, when they know that they should consider the published version to be just one experiment out of many in a normal series of experiments that are needed in proper software development. The same problem with corporate projects: one does not tell the manager that hey, I screwed up and I should just start the project all over with a different set of dependencies or with a different architecture. 


Thank You for reading my comment.
